metadata.description: Class 9 Science - Chapter 11: Work and Energy

question.text: (CBSE 2023) The SI unit of work is:
question.explanation: Work = Force × Displacement. SI unit: Joule (J) = N·m = kg·m²/s². Named after James Prescott Joule.

question.text: (SEBA 2023) The energy stored in a stretched spring is:
question.explanation: Stretched/compressed spring stores elastic PE = ½kx² where k = spring constant, x = displacement.

question.text: (CBSE 2022) A body of mass 1 kg is lifted through 1 m. Work done is: (g=10 m/s²)
question.explanation: Work = mgh = 1 × 10 × 1 = 10 J. Force needed = weight = mg = 10 N upward.

question.text: (SEBA 2022) The commercial unit of energy is:
question.explanation: 1 kWh = 3.6×10⁶ J. Used for electricity billing. 1 unit = 1 kWh.

question.text: (CBSE 2021) Which of these has greatest kinetic energy?
question.explanation: KE = ½mv². Compare: A) ½mv², B) ½(2m)(v/2)² = ¼mv², C) ½(m/2)(2v)² = mv². So C has maximum.

question.text: (SEBA 2021) The work done by centripetal force on a body in circular motion is:
question.explanation: Centripetal force is perpendicular to displacement (tangential) → θ = 90° → cos90° = 0 → Work = 0.

question.text: (CBSE 2020) Power is defined as:
question.explanation: Power = Rate of doing work = Work/time. SI unit: Watt (W) = J/s.

question.text: (SEBA 2020) The potential energy of a body at height h is:
question.explanation: Gravitational PE = mgh, where h measured from reference level (usually ground). PE increases with height.

question.text: (CBSE 2019) A boy carries a load on his head through horizontal road. Work done against gravity is:
question.explanation: Displacement horizontal, gravity vertical → θ = 90° → Work = Fd cos90° = 0. He does work against friction/muscular effort.

question.text: (SEBA 2019) The kinetic energy of a body of mass m moving with velocity v is:
question.explanation: KE = ½mv². Proportional to mass and square of velocity. Unit: Joule (same as work).

(SEBA 2018) The law of conservation of energy states:
question.explanation: Energy neither created nor destroyed, only transforms from one form to another. Total energy constant in isolated system.

question.text: Work is said to be done when:
question.explanation: Work = F·d·cosθ. Three conditions: 1) Force applied, 2) Displacement, 3) Component of force in direction of displacement.

question.text: When work is done on a body, its energy:
question.explanation: Work-energy theorem: Work done = change in kinetic energy. Positive work increases energy, negative work decreases.

question.text: A 2 kg mass moving at 3 m/s has kinetic energy:
The power of a pump lifting 100 kg water per minute from 10 m deep well is: (g=10 m/s²)
If velocity of a body is doubled, its kinetic energy becomes:
question.explanation: KE ∝ v². v → 2v → KE → (2)² = 4 times original.

question.text: A body at height h has potential energy 100 J. When fallen halfway, its PE is:
question.option: 0 J PE ∝ h. At h/2, PE = 100/2 = 50 J (assuming reference at ground). Lost 50 J converts to KE.

question.text: Which is NOT a unit of energy?
question.explanation: Watt is power (J/s). Energy units: Joule, calorie (4.184 J), erg (10⁻⁷ J), eV (1.6×10⁻¹⁹ J).

question.text: A man pushes a wall but fails to move it. Work done is:
question.explanation: No displacement → work = 0. Energy spent but no mechanical work (converts to heat in muscles).

question.text: When a spring is compressed, the work done on it is stored as:
question.explanation: Spring stores elastic PE = ½kx². Released → converts to KE. Examples: toy gun, trampoline.

question.text: The work done by gravity on a freely falling body is:
question.explanation: Gravity downward, displacement downward → θ = 0° → cos0° = 1 → positive work. Converts PE to KE.

question.text: If mass and speed both are doubled, kinetic energy becomes:
question.explanation: KE ∝ m and ∝ v². m→2m, v→2v → KE → 2 × (2)² = 2 × 4 = 8 times.

question.text: A 100 W bulb operates for 10 hours. Energy consumed is:
question.explanation: Energy = Power × time = 100 W × 10 h = 1000 Wh = 1 kWh = 1 unit.

question.text: The potential energy of a body depends on:
question.explanation: Gravitational PE depends on height (mgΔh). Elastic PE depends on deformation (½kx²). Chemical PE on composition.

question.text: A machine does 1000 J work in 5 seconds. Its power is:
question.explanation: Power = Work/time = 1000 J/5 s = 200 W.

question.text: In which case is work done negative?
question.explanation: Lowering weight: force upward (to control), displacement downward → θ = 180° → cos180° = -1 → negative work.

question.text: The kinetic energy of a body becomes 4 times when its:
question.explanation: KE ∝ v². Double v → KE ×4. Double mass → KE ×2 only.

question.text: A 50 kg man runs up stairs of total height 4 m in 5 s. His power is: (g=10 m/s²)
Energy transformation in electric heater is:
question.explanation: Electric heater: electrical energy → heat energy (Joule heating). Efficiency nearly 100%.

question.text: The work done in lifting a 5 kg mass through 2 m is: (g=10 m/s²)
question.explanation: Work against gravity = mgh = 5×10×2 = 100 J.

question.text: When a body falls freely, its total energy:
question.explanation: Conservation of mechanical energy: PE + KE = constant (if no air resistance). PE converts to KE.

question.text: 1 calorie equals:
question.explanation: 1 cal = 4.184 J (approximately 4.2 J). Nutritional Calorie (capital C) = 1000 cal = 4184 J.

question.text: A force of 10 N displaces a body by 5 m at angle 60°. Work done is:
Which has maximum kinetic energy?
question.explanation: Calculate KE: A) ½×1×4=2 J, B) ½×2×1=1 J, C) ½×0.5×16=4 J, D) ½×4×0.25=0.5 J. C maximum.

question.text: The work-energy theorem states:
question.explanation: Theorem: Net work done = Final KE - Initial KE = ΔKE. Connects work and energy concepts.

question.text: A body of mass 2 kg has 16 J kinetic energy. Its speed is:
question.option: 8 m/s KE = ½mv² → 16 = ½×2×v² → v² = 16 → v = 4 m/s.

question.text: The energy stored in fossil fuels is:
question.option: Mechanical energy Fossil fuels (coal, oil, gas) store chemical energy from ancient plants/animals, released by combustion.

question.text: A light and heavy body have same kinetic energy. Which has greater momentum?
question.option: Both equal Cannot say KE = p²/2m. For same KE, p ∝ √m. Heavier body has greater momentum.
